Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208 (statutory provisions governing custody and visitation/modification);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, \u00a7 51A.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 119, § 51A (duties to report child abuse/neglect where applicable);

Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C.proposition: Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C (paternity, where relevant to parental status and custody);

Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).proposition: Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000) (parental rights/constitutional framework for parental decisionmaking);
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).support_reasoning: Troxel squarely addresses and articulates the constitutional framework for parental decisionmaking, recognizing under the Fourteenth Amendment a fundamental liberty interest of parents in the care, custody, and control of their children and invalidating a state statute that allowed broad third‑party visitation based only on a judge’s view of the child’s best interests. The plurality, concurrence, and Thomas’s opinion all root the decision in substantive due process protection for parental rights, making the case a leading authority on constitutional parental rights and limits on state interference with parental decisions.
Troxel v. Granville, 530 U.S. 57 (2000).relevant_excerpt: “The liberty interest at issue in this case—the interest of parents in the care, custody, and control of their children—is perhaps the oldest of the fundamental liberty interests recognized by this Court… In light of this extensive precedent, it cannot now be doubted that the Due Process Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment protects the fundamental right of parents to make decisions concerning the care, custody, and control of their children.” (530 U.S. at 65–66)

Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).proposition: Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982) (parental liberty interest principles);
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely recognizes and articulates the fundamental liberty interest of natural parents in the care, custody, and management of their children as protected by the Fourteenth Amendment, and explains that this interest does not disappear even when parents have been neglectful or have temporarily lost custody. The Court then uses that parental liberty interest to hold that heightened procedural protections (a clear and convincing evidence standard) are required before the State may permanently terminate parental rights. That directly supports citing Santosky for “parental liberty interest principles.”
Santosky v. Kramer, 455 U.S. 745 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “The absence of dispute reflected this Court’s historical recognition that freedom of personal choice in matters of family life is a fundamental liberty interest protected by the Fourteenth Amendment. … The fundamental liberty interest of natural parents in the care, custody, and management of their child does not evaporate simply because they have not been model parents or have lost temporary custody of their child to the State. … When the State moves to destroy weakened familial bonds, it must provide the parents with fundamentally fair procedures.”
